dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSE LORKOWSKI, 30, drives through Albuquerque. She passe small adobe houses, the Air force base, parched earth playgrounds, University cafes and other distinctive sight On the   highway she passes under the freeway interchange tangle   of rust and turquoise ramps. The Sandia mountain in the   distance as Rose heads up to the nicer neighborh of the   foothills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls up to an expensive looking Spanish style house parks. She gets out of the car, pops the hatch and pulls a vacuum cleaner and assorted cleaning supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose drags a vacuum cleaner into a room where expensive d collides with the debris of a recent party. She collects beer bottles from end tables, book shelves a house plants. Cigarette butts float in cocktail glasses. Rose plugs in the vacuum cord and glances out the sliding glass doors. A group of twenty somethings frolic in the p A lanky trust funder slides open the door and drips water onto the carpet as he makes his way to retrieve a cold be He brushes past Rose on his way back out. Rose turns on t vacuum and wonders if he even saw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The space is packed with every kind of snack imaginable. LORKOWSKI, 53, talks as the OWNER stocks shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the five stores here and then two in Rio Rancho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fantastic. See, if we're talking that kind of volume I can absolutely massage the numbers a little. Seriously, you're not gonna be able to keep it on the shelf. Joe pulls out some order forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'd need to look at some things before I can place an order. The owner looks at Joe's business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about I give you a call if I decide to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you. Not a problem. No problem at all. Even better, I'll swing by. You're on my route. How `bout that? I'll swing by tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, tomorrow's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday then. That's better anyway. That'll give you a chance to take a look see on those other stores. We'll put everything on one order and get you a good price break. The owner seems to consider the offer. Joe scans the shel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My advice to you - weed out some of this weaker product to make more space for the corn. Like this... Joe reaches over and grabs a packet of organic fruit bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apricot Fruit Leather. Whose bright idea was it to stock that? I mean come on, what self respecting kid asks his mom for apricot fruit leather?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The owner is not amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe pulls a hand cart stacked high with Fancy Corn canist to his rusted Monte Carlo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the glass pane we see disgruntled waitress, NORAH LORKOWSKI (25). She appears to be in a heated argument wi MR. KIM, the restaurant owner. A customer watches the exchange with amusement. Norah takes off her apron, throws it at Mr. Kim. Norah ex the restaurant. Mr. Kim trails her. Then MRS. KIM notices joins the fray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I so don't care. Norah flips him off and walk down the street. As she continues to walk she realizes that quitting her job migh not have been the best decision ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A banana floats in the toilet. OSCAR LORKOWSKI, 7, smiles kicks the flush lever. Whoosh... the banana is sucked dow the drain. Gone. Well, not quite. Oscar watches water fill the basin and s onto the floor. Oscar turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar steps from the bathroom and walks quickly down the empty hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUSINESSMAN removes a single shotgun shell from the glo compartment. He drops it in his shirt pocket, sprays brea freshener in his mouth and gets out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The businessman approaches the gun display and points to shotgun. An employee hands him the gun and turns his attention to another customer. The businessman reaches into his pocket and pulls out the shotgun shell. Loads it. Draws the barrel up under his ch A Bubba pricing camouflaged vests nearby notices the businessman. His expression shifts from concern to alarm horrible anticipation. He braces for the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police mill about and question people. CARL SWANSON, a 40 man sporting a crew cut and a `Above and Beyond' polo shi talks to the STORE OWNER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, these shotgun cases are a real pain in the ass. What we call a wide field of contamination.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CARL (cont'd) Guy's all over the place and every little glob of him's a biohazard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner rubs his temples. CARL Gonna lose some inventory. OWNER Selfish bastard. CARL Trust me, you do not want some lady suing you cuz she found this guy's tooth in her brand new fanny pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ABOVE AND BEYOND WORKER in a polo shirt waves his arm t get Carl's attention. CLEAN SWEEP WORKER He's over here in fishing too. CARL Yep, a real pain in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl walks over to his assistant. Detective, `MAC' MACDOW approaches the owner. MAC We're wrapping it up. OWNER Three grand just to have the asshole wiped up off the floor. Can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac and another DETECTIVE walk toward the entrance. MAC Hey, can you handle the report tonight? I gotta thing I gotta do. DETECTIVE A blonde thing or a brunette thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose steps from the shower. She is attractive with sharp features and eyes that hint at future crow's feet. Her confidence has grown brittle by the gnawing fear that lif peaked as the captain of the high school cheerleading squ

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A note taped to the bathroom mirror reads: `You are stron You are powerful. You can do anything. You are a winner.' Rose wipes condensation from the mirror to reveal her fac ROSE I am strong. I am powerful. I can do anything. I am a winner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't look like she believes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah lounges on her bed and loads weed onto a jerry-rigg pop-can-pipe. NORAH The fact that we have sex, real coitus sex, means I'm under no obligation to blow you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah fires up the bud, inhales deeply and passes the can RANDY, a good-looking redneck in his early 20's. RANDY I think you're scared of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Norah opens a book about sign language and starts practic the sign alphabet. A-B-C-D-E-F. F is a hard one. NORAH (Holding in the smoke) I'm not scared of it. RANDY Uncomfortable then. You just need to get better acquainted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah exhales. Randy stands and takes off his pants. The phone RINGS again. NORAH (yelling) Dad, get the phone. RANDY There's absolutely no pressure here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Randy lies next to Norah naked from the waist down. Norah ignores him and continues forming letters with her finger She jots a note and sticks the pencil behind her ear. The phone RINGS again. Norah reaches across Randy and pic up the receiver. RANDY You can touch it if you want. NORAH (into phone) Hello. ROSE (O.S.) (through receiver) You haven't left yet? Damn it Norah, my class starts in fifteen minutes. NORAH (into phone) I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Norah holds the phone her eyes slide from Randy's face his off screen penis. She takes the pencil from behind he ear and, in the way you'd poke a hamster to see if it is or merely sleeping, prods Randy's off screen penis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits in the living room, busily putting stickers on c of Fancy Corn. Norah and Randy enter from Norah's room. JOE                                           * Doesn't Rose have her thing                             * tonight?                                                * NORAH                                         * I'm going. I need to borrow your                        * car.                                                    * JOE                                           * Here. Take some corn.                                   *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah leaves. Randy and Joe share an awkward silence. RANDY                                         * I'm really nuts about your                              * daughter, Mr. Lorkowski.                                *

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE                                             * That's nice. Give me a hand with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put stickers on popcorn cans. RANDY                                           * I see they sold that house across the street. I bet they'll come knocking on your door soon. JOE                                             * They can knock all they want. Wait, wait, whaddaya doing? Don't put the lime sticker on the cheddar can. Maybe I better just do this myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy pulls up to a small house and stops. Norah gets out collects the canister from back and heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah enters the tidy two bedroom house with a barrel of Fancy Corn under her arm. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be so late. Oscar runs from the bedroom and flings himself onto Norah Pale and skinny, Oscar is the kind of kid easily picked o in slaughter-ball. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought fancy corn! ROSE (Looking for her purse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you eat that stuff? Norah and Oscar both jam a handful into their mouths. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be hyper all night. Rose finds her purse and quickly puts on lipstick. She le down and gives Oscar a kiss on the forehead. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be good.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns to Norah. ROSE And no lobsterman stories. He had nightmares all week. (opening the door) Just use some common sense. NORAH You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose lies on her back being fucked. Her head nearly hits headboard with each thrust. ROSE You want me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose closes her eyes. Her head starts to thump the headbo MAC (Rhythmically) Yeah... baby... I want... Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar and Norah lie in Oscar's little bed. Oscar holds th covers tight under his chin. Norah drinks a beer. There's half eaten canister of `Fancy Corn' between them. NORAH He's slowly freezing to death and he knows lobsterman is out there... somewhere... coming for him. And he's totally screwed because his tongue is stuck to the mailbox. OSCAR Why did he lick the mailbox? NORAH I don't know. Maybe he had OCD and he was obsessed with licking mailboxes. OSCAR Why wasn't he in school?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH Are you gonna let me tell the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar nods. NORAH An then, he hears a horrible sound. Snap, snap, drag. Snap, snap, drag. Lobsterman is coming. OSCAR Maybe he didn't go to school because he had the ACD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah looks at Oscar. OSCAR Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah downs the last swig of beer and sets the bottle dow next to another empty. NORAH He's trapped. If he doesn't rip the skin off his tongue and make a run for it lobsterman will tear him to pieces with his razor sharp claws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtains drawn in the cheap hotel room. Rose gets out of and pulls on her clothes. Mac watches for a moment, then rolls out of bed. He stops. Grimaces. ROSE Still sore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac shakes his head and pretends not to be. ROSE I don't know why you did that. MAC You should hear the way he goes on about his lean body mass index bullshit. Drinking that antioxidant, protein powder, enzyme crap all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac limps over to his clothes hanging over a chair.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE When was the last time you even played basketball? MAC He needed to be brought down a peg or two. ROSE I'm sure you pulling a groin muscle humbled him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose smiles and Mac pretends to be offended. MAC I should introduce him to your sister. ROSE Norah and a cop? That would happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac shrugs and steps into his slacks. MAC We were working a scene today where this guy offs himself in a sporting goods store. So they had this cleaning crew out there, right? You would not believe how much money they charge for that shit. It's ridiculous. ROSE With the dead body there? MAC Naw, the body's gone, it's just the blood and stuff. ROSE Sounds horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose peels the backing off a nicotine patch and carefully sticks it on her arm. MAC You ask me it's a racket. You should get into that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose slips on her blouse looks at Mac.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that's all I can do? Clean other people's shit? MAC (He sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here. Rose steps toward him and eyes Mac as he buttons her blou MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that's not what I think. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am gonna be a real estate agent. Rose rubs the nicotine patch on her arm. Mac nods and smi MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. With business cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah holds a lit joint out the window and watches a chee TV movie circa 1982. Big hair and leg warmers. Norah lean out the window and exhales, takes another toke. The sound of a key at the door prompts Norah to quickly s out the joint and close the window. Rose opens the door. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time. I thought your class got over at 9:30. Rose looks at Oscar sprawled out asleep on the couch. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why isn't he in bed? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said he was scared. I think he was fakin' it though. Rose fumbles in her purse and pulls out a ten-dollar bill NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not taking money. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just ten bucks, take it. Dad told me about you getting fired.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norah makes a face like `great, here it comes.' ROSE What happened? NORAH Nothing. ROSE What, were you stoned or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah waves her hand dismissively. NORAH It was just Mr. Kim being a dick head. ROSE I thought you liked Mr. Kim. NORAH Yeah, before Mrs. Kim started working there. Now he's a full on gym teacher, I swear to God. ROSE When are you going to grow up and start taking responsibility for-- NORAH Oh please, you love it when I fuck up. Love it. Me screwing up gives you the hugest woody. ROSE Shut up and take the ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah takes the ten. Rose looks at the TV. NORAH There was a diner scene earlier. With a waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks at Norah. ROSE Any pie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah smiles and opens the door to leave. NORAH Completely pie free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose wraps the vacuum cleaner cord while another MOLLY MA wipes down the last window. Through the window, a smartly dressed pregnant woman walk toward the house with shopping bags in hand. MOLLY MAID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady's here. Rose nods and heads downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULA DATZMAN-MEAD sets her bags down on the table and fi a checkbook from her purse. Rose enters with the vacuum cleaner in tow. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all finished. Since it's our first visit we did the blinds and appliances but normally we'll alternate those weekly. Nobody mentioned anything to us about laundry so we didn't bother with that but if you want laundry included there is an extra... PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose? Rose Lorkowski? Startled, Rose looks the woman in the eye for the first t PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Paula Datzman... cheerleading squad junior year. Recognition punches Rose in the face. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula Datzman. Wow. Awkward silence. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! I'm Paula Datzman-Mead now.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE Congratulations. PAULA Thanks. We're expecting our second in a couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula pats her swollen belly and Rose forces a smile. PAULA How are you? You look just the same. ROSE I'm good. Really good! PAULA God, I always envied you so much. Head cheerleader... dating the quarterback... So did you and Mac end up getting married? ROSE Nope. No. (Awkward silence) I'm not sure...I think he ended up marrying Heather Volkman. PAULA Wow. Well it's so good to see you. Let me get your info so I can send you an invite to the baby shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula gets a piece of paper and a pen and hands it to Ros PAULA It'll be like a big reunion. The whole gang from high school will be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose writes her number and address on the scrap of paper. PAULA So what are you doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woops. Paula immediately regrets the question. ROSE I... I've just gotten my real estate license, and so...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real estate? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this... this is just kind of a temporary thing and I'm about to just really phase over into the real estate full time. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding, I'm in real estate! Paula pulls a business card from her purse and hands it t Rose. The card has a picture of Paula's smiling face. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Long and Foster. Who are you with? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Um. You know, I haven't really decided yet. I might check out Long and Foster. Paula nods. Uncomfortable. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll just be independent. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe. They grasp for something to say. They fail. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that about the laundry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose caries a vacuum cleaner and bucket of cleaning suppl out to a rusted Nissan Sentra with a Molly Maid door magn She throws the vacuum and bucket in the back hatch, start close it, then stops. Rose walks to the side of the car, peels off the Molly Ma magnet and throws that in as well. She looks at the Datzm Mead house with a mixture of resentment and shame. She gets into the car and cries. Her cell phone rings. Sh digs the phone out of her bag and tries to steady her voi

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar sits outside the counselor's office on a bench. He cranes his neck to watch the secretary typing forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sits nervously across from the school COUNSELOR, a serious man in his mid forties and a TEACHER with cotton candy hair. The man speaks first. COUNSELOR It's not just this incident. There have been several episodes over the past year where Oscar has... has engaged in disruptive behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose shifts her eyes from the counselor to the teacher an back to the counselor. COUNSELOR There was the incident in gym class. ROSE I did pay the damages for that. COUNSELOR And the chalk thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose bites a fingernail. COUNSELOR And the time he locked Jeremy Johnston in the-- ROSE Okay. What did he do this time? COUNSELOR Now it's... licking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TEACHER I will not tolerate it. I will not tolerate that behavior in my classroom. COUNSELOR Oscar has started licking things in the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks even more confused. TEACHER First it was the pencil sharpener. Then the aquarium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The secretary stops typing and offers a sympathetic glanc Oscar. He capitalizes on the moment by licking the wall. COUNSELOR (O.S.) It's unsanitary. And it's disturbing to the other children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The secretary recoils and returns to her typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The counselor leans forward with genuine concern. COUNSELOR We think Oscar might benefit from an environment where he could receive more specialized attention. TEACHER He licked my leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar finds Joe asleep on the Lazy Boy. He snores in that scary sleep apnea way В­ holding his breath between snore Oscar notices a leather strap hanging down from the top s of a book case. He pulls up a chair to investigate. The strap leads to an old pair of binoculars. Behind it, dusty books about birds. Oscar grabs the binoculars and climbs down. Oscar holds the binoculars to his face but the lenses are far apart. Oscar compensates by closing one eye and looki through only one lens. He focuses on his grandpa's nose h Joe wakes. JOE Where'd you get those? OSCAR Up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar points to the book shelf. Something sad stirs in Jo JOE Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar steps closer. Joe twists something on the binocular and pushes the lenses closer together to accommodate Osca small face. Better. JOE Those were your grandma's. She'd watch birds with those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar walks around the room examining various objects and clunks them against a lamp in the process. JOE Hey, hey. Careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe holds out his hand to retrieve the binoculars. JOE Why don't we put those away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar doesn't want to. He hesitates. Joe raises an eyebro Oscar shuffles back to his grampa and hands them over.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OSCAR Why can't I play with them? JOE Because it's not a toy. It's a scientific instrument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar's disappointed. JOE You can play with them when I'm around to supervise. OSCAR You're around now. JOE I'm tired now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe studies the binoculars for a moment and then sets the back on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose shakes her head and hands Norah another dish. ROSE Well I'm not putting him in special ed. I'll figure out a way to put him in private school before I do that. NORAH Rose, you buy generic cigarettes with couch change. How are you gonna pay for private school? JOE Who's going to private school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose turns and sees her dad leaning in the door way. ROSE Nobody dad, we're just talking. JOE Oscar get suspended again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE The kid's a little strange. What? That's against the law now? It's not like he's out killing kittens or any damn thing. I swear everyone's so damn uptight these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar rides a mechanical horse. Rose pushes a cart down the isle and dials her cell phone She grabs a box of cereal and tosses it in her cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac sits at the table with a cup of coffee and reads the paper. A young girl holds out the telephone. MAC Hello.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE CONVERSATION
dialogues.text: ROSE Mac, it's me. MAC What are you doing calling here? ROSE I know, I'm sorry. MAC Heather could have easily-- ROSE I thought she had yoga on Saturdays. MAC Still, it's not cool.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE I know, I'm sorry. I just needed to ask you... you know the other day... you said that... about the specialized cleaning guys making so much money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Oscar walk to the car with the groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lorkowski family dines in style. ROSE (O.S.) Are you even listening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah turns to face Rose at the other side of the table. NORAH No thanks. ROSE What do you mean `no thanks'? What else do you have to do? You don't have a job. You don't go to school. What, are you going to live with Dad the rest of your life? NORAH I don't think you're in any position to feel superior.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE Girls, come on. Lets have a nice dinner. ROSE It's just until I get my real estate license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff sings a BIRTHDAY SONG at a table nearby. OSCAR I want to have my birthday at Hinkle's. JOE The hell with Hinkle's, I'm taking us to Disney Land!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar's eyes light up as he smiles at Joe. ROSE Dad don't. OSCAR Why? I think Disney Land is a great idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose gives Joe a sharp look. JOE Yeah, what's wrong with Disney Land? And I think it'd be great if you girls worked together. NORAH You are so out of touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large bellied SUPERINTENDENT leads Rose and Norah up a flight of stairs. Beads of sweat drip from his doughy fac SUPER Some sorta domestic disturbance kind of a deal. It was the lady who got the last word I guess. Course she's in jail now, so... Heard one bullet completely shot off his ring finger. How long you gals been doin' this kind a work?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE A while.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SUPER (Checking out Rose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Mac pretty well? Norah shoots Rose a look. Rose doesn't answer. They arriv the door of the apartment. The super unlocks the door. SUPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just swing by the office when you're done and we'll settle up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah step into the apartment littered with dirt dishes and clothes. Rose walks down the hall while Norah examines a plastic b with top hat. It tips down and drinks from the glass. ROSE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah and Rose stand frozen at the threshold. They are aw struck by the horrible scene in front of them. Blooms of splattered blood dry on tile walls. It gathers sticky brown lines around grout. The mirror is broken. Th shower curtain hangs half torn. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think they loved each other? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands pull on yellow cleaning gloves. Pinkish foam slides down Norah's glove as she scrubs bloo grout with a toothbrush. Metal shower rings CLINK against the metal bar as Rose pu down the shower curtain. A rag is wrung out in a bucket of reddish water.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah clean in silence. Reverent but detached. T way you would act at a stranger's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah puts blood spattered towels into a washing machine. She spots a dish on the dryer filled with pennies and but and other odds and ends. She fishes out a PINK CANDY HEAR It reads, `Luv U 4 ever'. Norah pockets the candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah gather their cleaning supplies and stand b to admire their handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah hangs back while the super hands Rose a check. SUPER You gals did a real nice job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rose turns to leave she flashes the check to Norah. Fi hundred bucks. Rose raises an eyebrow. Cha-ching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks though a low rent part of town carrying a barre Fancy Corn. He ducks into the neighborhood bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe enters a dingy little corner bar where everyone's a regular. A couple of old guys slump over the bar. The BARTENDER smiles. BARTENDER Hey Joe, what you got for me? JOE World's finest corn snack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hands the canister to the bartender and sits down on stool. The bartender pours him a beer.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BARTENDER See where old Miller's house sold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe nods. A grizzled REGULAR nearby looks over at Joe. REGULAR Bet you could get a chunk of change for your place. You should cash out now before the market turns sour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe shakes his head. JOE I'm not selling my house. No way. I don't care how much those idiots would shell out for it. I got history in that house. You think they understand about history? REGULAR Still... How much commission you get on that popcorn? Bet you gotta sell a lot of corn to- JOE Hey, the corn's good. Really good. Not like the pet food but that was a phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender sets a basket of cheddar popcorn in the spa between Joe and the grizzled regular. JOE It'll get there. Takes time to get to know the market. Develop a relationship with the buyers. But it'll get there. Who doesn't like popcorn for Christ's sake. REGULAR My brother-in-law's in sales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regular scoops up a handful of powdery orange popcorn REGULAR Last year he buys a cow. JOE Why would you buy a cow?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: REGULAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a live cow. A whole butchered cow from a rancher. On the hoof they call it. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm hmm. Joe looks at him with renewed interest. REGULAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sells off the parts of this cow to a bunch of restaurants. Direct. Made a killing. The grizzled man licks orange powder from his fingers. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he do with the brains and intestines? Regular shrugs. Joe's wheels are turning. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he cuts out the middle man. Not a bad idea. Joe takes a drink of his beer while he mulls it over. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course it'd be smarter to do that with something that didn't have bad parts. Like... shrimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day in paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah sleeps in her clothes and makeup from the previous night. Knocking wakes her. JOE (though the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is on the phone. Norah? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE She says it's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With great effort Norah picks up the receiver. NORAH What do you want? ROSE Mac got us another gig. NORAH I'm sleeping. ROSE I'll pick you up in an hour. NORAH No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose's Nissan rolls down a rough looking Albuquerque stre toward a trailer park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sips her 7-11 coffee. Norah stares blank and blood-s NORAH You suck. ROSE Money. NORAH You still suck. ROSE Apparently some crazy bag lady squatter person died and-- NORAH You didn't get me coffee? ROSE I didn't know you wanted any. NORAH Of course I...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norah shakes her head in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose turns into the trailer park, heads past a row of trailers, and parks. Rose and Norah get out of the car and approach a particul run down trailer. NORAH How long is this gonna take? ROSE All we have to do is go in and throw everything away. Cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah open the door and the rancid sweet smell o decayed flesh splashes them in the face. They lift their shirts up over their noses and walk inside. Old newspapers stacked to the ceiling. Piles of trash lea like snowdrifts against the wall. Cat food encrusted plat Norah opens the bedroom door and peeks in. Flies BUZZ. Sh darts to another room and retches. ROSE Great, now we're gonna have to clean that up too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose walks into the bedroom, blanches and stifles a gag reflex. Norah storms past Rose and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose chases after Norah and grabs her arm. ROSE Where are you going? NORAH There is no way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah shakes off Rose and walks down the row of trailers.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE You said you would help me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH (without turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if you'd gotten me a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls her shirt off and wraps it around her head so only her eyes are exposed. She strains to open a window that's been painted shut. Sh bangs and pulls but it doesn't budge. Rose finds a can of beans and whacks them against the bas the window in an attempt to break the seal. Rose grows mo desperate with each failed effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah watches Rose struggle with the window. Pigeons gather at her feet and she gives a little kick. Birdseed tumbles on to her shoe. She turns. A weathered man sits outside his small rectangular castle tosses birdseed to the pigeons. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm standing here. Norah looks back up to Rose still struggling with the win Finally, Rose muscles it open and throws Norah an angry l of triumph. There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Oscar drive to a potential sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah ties a shirt around her face as she enters. They turn their attention to the discolored mattress attracting flies in the corner. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do with that? Rose shrugs. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE Dumpster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah lift the mattress and drag it to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah struggle to transport the stinking mattres the dumpster. It is a clumsy process. The thing tips and falls on Norah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tucked inside a mall, the candy store does brisk business Pimple-faced clerks ring up clumps of overweight families Oscar pretends to look at hard candies while he listens t Joe and the MANAGER. MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me this Fancy Corn stuff is some kind of health food? JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a candy... and a health food. Absolutely. Absolutely. MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't know. We don't have much more shelf space. Oscar spots a GIRL perusing wax lips. She looks to be abo five or six. Joe ignores the manager and reads ingredient off a Twizzler package. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glycerol monostearate? What is that? I can't even read that. Joe spins a can of Fancy Corn around and points to the ingredients. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read that. The manager leans close. MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High fructose-- JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The first thing listed. The number one ingredient.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MANAGER Corn. JOE Exactly. Corn. Can you think of anything more wholesome? It's all American for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager's not buying it. Oscar takes action. He posit himself next to the girl. OSCAR Do you know if they sell fancy corn here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl looks at him suspiciously. OSCAR Do you even know what fancy corn is? GIRL Yes. OSCAR Well, do they sell it here? GIRL I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back to the lips and tries to ignore Oscar. OSCAR I heard that the strawberry fancy corn gives you bionic strength. GIRL That's stupid. OSCAR It's true. Some kind of chemical in the strawberry flavoring. If you eat a whole lot of it, it gives you bionic strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl gives Oscar a long stare. GIRL I don't believe you. OSCAR I don't care if you do or not.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girl watches him for a moment and then walks over and tugs her mother's shirt. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read where these chemicals are getting into the streams, making hermaphrodidic frogs! You think mothers want to expose their kids to that stuff? No way. More and more people are looking for healthy alternatives which is why the demand for this product is so huge right now. MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, I already put in all the orders I want for this year. Just then, the GIRL'S MOTHER walks up to the manager. GIRL'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Do you carry something called fancy corn? Joe looks at Oscar. Oscar smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREEN REVISION 3/5/07      29-30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much progress has been made on the trailer. Rose and Nora work on the last remaining piles of trash. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems wrong though doesn't it... to throw everything away. Rose tosses a tattered fanny pack onto the heap in the garbage can. Norah plucks it out and opens it. Norah pulls out a PHOTO ID. She holds it up. The woman on ID looks street-worn and crazy. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet this is her. Rose sweeps. Norah digs deeper into the fanny pack and pu out a small packet wrapped in satin ribbon. Norah unties the ribbon and finds a stack of old school photos. Each photo is of a different grade. Norah flips through the stack and the girl appears to grow up. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, look at this. Norah holds the senior photo next to the ID. The resembla between the two is clear. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think it's her daughter? Rose looks. Shrugs. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we do something? Try to find her or something? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's none of your business, Norah.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose picks up a bag stuffed with cans and fast food wrapp She screams and drops the bag. A giant ball of maggots writhes at her feet. ROSE (pointing) Hand me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah grabs the dust pan and hands it to Rose. NORAH What if she doesn't know? Wouldn't you want to know if this was mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah looks closely at the I.D. as Rose deposits trash an maggots into the garbage bin. The comparison angers Rose. ROSE Mom was never like this. Mom would never have been like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah thinks about that and looks back at the I.D. NORAH I wonder how she died? ROSE Damnit Norah, we still have a lot of shit to do here. Are you just gonna talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Oscar roll a handcart strapped with Fancy Corn canisters through the parking lot to the car. JOE That was real good. You're a natural. You got the timing, you got the nerve. You're a real sharp cookie, you know that? OSCAR No I'm not. I'm stupid. JOE You're not stupid. What are you saying? You're not stupid.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OSCAR Yes I am. They want to put me in retard classes. JOE Don't say that. OSCAR What? JOE It's those teachers who are retarded. You're probably just too advanced for those classes. You're bored. Do you get bored in class? OSCAR Yeah. JOE See. You're too smart! And those teachers just don't know how to handle you. You're probably a goddamn genius. OSCAR You think so? JOE I know so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weeds grow in the yard of the small house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah empties the contents of the fanny pack onto her bed She examines the photos and picks up what appears to be a senior photo. She turns it over and sees, written on the back, LYNN WISEMAN - 1998.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose's Sentra is again parked next to the blue Camry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same room as before. Same curtains drawn. Mac unzips Rose skirt and kisses her neck. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so disgusting. I mean the smell, you would not believe. Mac's in the sex zone. He unbuttons his shirt and tunes o all those distracting words tumbling from Rose's mouth. Rose, animated, slips her skirt off and tosses it aside. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were flies everywhere and, really, the smell. I can't even describe it. Mac's shoes hit the floor with a thud. He sets his belt a gun on the dresser. MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Rose pulls her shirt over her head. Mac kisses her belly. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, after we finished... you woulda never even known. We took all that away... made it right. Mac pulls off his pants. Rose hangs her bra on the back o the chair and slips off her undies. MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you... I mean, I feel like I got you into this mess. Her sense of pride wilts. Her hand instinctively reaches to massage the nicotine patch on her arm. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I-- MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm gonna pay for new real estate classes. Okay? Rose looks at Mac. Shrugs. Mac smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAC We'll get you your license and then get you a little photo in the real estate section. You can drive people around all day and talk about... Gosh, what would you talk about? (Suddenly very serious) Crown molding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose smiles. Apparently it's some private joke. ROSE Oh yeah, definitely talk about crown molding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phrase seems to send a ripple of pleasure through Mac ROSE Property easements, square footage, appliances...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac reacts to each word as if it were some filthy sex tal He looks at Rose and raises an eyebrow. MAC You're holding out on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose rolls her eyes and laughs. ROSE Freak. MAC Say it. Come on. One time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and shakes her head. Mac waits. Rose relents. ROSE Curb appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac growls and pounces on Rose. It's fun and light. Rose laughs while Mac makes a show of mauling her neck. He falls on the bed and reaches out. Rose takes his hand. It's rough against hers. There's a circular indentation w his wedding ring isn't. Rose stops laughing. She touches the invisible ring. ROSE Why'd you pick her?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mac looks up. Buzz kill. The residue of a smile fades. MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it wasn't like that. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it like? He takes a step back. MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to do that? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. MAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is going to get all heavy-- ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Rose turns around and kisses Mac. One of those soft, teas kisses that ends with a look that kicks things in gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls her car up to one of many warehouses in the ar and double checks the address on a scrap of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah enter this no frills operation. Cinder blo walls and concrete floors. A small TV on the front counte offers up a not-so-classic afternoon movie line up. As they approach, the clerk drops out of sight behind the counter. Rose leans over to see the clerk on his knees searching for something small and lost. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston? WINSTON, 35, crudely handsome with dark unkempt hair and lips, looks up. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke with you on the phone. I'm Rose Lorkowski.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose sticks out her right hand. Winston stands to reveal he is missing his right arm. He clumsily shakes her hand with his left. ROSE So, our situation is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the TV, a waitress enters the frame. Rose stops. She a Norah both turn and look at the TV. The waitress pours coffee and exits the frame without a w Rose and Norah turn back to Winston. Rose continues. ROSE We're doing some postmortem kind of um... specialized cleaning stuff and we had this really difficult... NORAH Smelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks at Norah and nods. ROSE Really smelly job where the lady had died and they didn't find her for a while and it was really... NORAH Stinky. ROSE The odor was really strong. WINSTON A decomp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose smiles a little too enthusiastically. ROSE Yeah, a decomp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston motions them to follow him through the store. He indicates points of interest with a flat monotone voice. WINSTON General purpose cleaners, extraction cleaners, odor control. We carry both the Winzyme and the DR 450. Disinfectants, stain removers and shampoos. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WINSTON (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steamers, buffers, foggers, that kinda stuff's in there, for rent or purchase. Quick absorbing sawdust, good for vomit. The tour ends at the back corner where respirators, safet glasses, gloves and Tyvec coveralls crowd the shelves. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've got your personal protective gear back here. The door BEEPS as it opens. CARL SWANSON walks in wearing `Above and Beyond' polo shirt. Winston returns to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl grabs a case of disinfectant and sets it on the coun Winston pulls out some paperwork. CARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear there're a couple of amateurs poaching jobs? Winston shakes his head. Rose and Norah make their way to the counter with arms fu of supplies and stand within earshot of Carl and Winston. CARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce said they took a decomp for five hundred bucks. What do you wanna bet they threw all that shit right in the dumpster. Norah nudges Rose. Carl pays and Rose and Norah watch him leave. They step up and set their supplies on the counter As Winston rings them up, Rose notices the shellacked puz picture of a big white cat on the wall. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I have that puzzle. It's a hard one. I think I got lost in the white and gave up. Rose flashes a `captain of the cheerleading squad' smile. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-eight twenty-four.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE You like cats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston looks squarely at Rose and steps into the back ro NORAH Great. You freaked him out. ROSE I asked him if he liked cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston returns with several books and pamphlets. Hazmat Guidelines, Biohazard Recovery and Disposal, etc. WINSTON Bring these back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose drives while Norah scans one of the books. NORAH Turns out it's against the law to throw bio hazards in the dumpster. Who knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose processes the visit. NORAH How perfect was he with the one arm? ROSE Hmm? NORAH The creepy guy. Do you think he was born like that? ROSE I didn't think he was creepy. NORAH Dude, he has one arm. ROSE They think we're just a couple of hacks. NORAH We are a couple of hacks.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norah looks out the window. NORAH Stop here. ROSE Why? NORAH I gotta thing. Just drop me off here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks confused but pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah opens the door and slides out. ROSE I'll drop Oscar by around seven. NORAH (sarcastically) You have class tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose smiles uncomfortably. ROSE Mortgage lenders and financing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah shakes her head in disgust. NORAH Heather's pregnant again. Did you know that? He's never going to leave her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose clenches her jaw and picks at a crack in the steerin wheel. Norah gets out of the car. NORAH God, you're pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah slams the door and watches Rose drive off. Norah stands at the door well and scans the apartment num listings. She sees the name she's looking for, LYNN WISEM Just then, LYNN, the woman from the photos, opens the doo and walks past. Caught off guard, Norah follows her.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOWING THROUGH STREETS
dialogues.text: They walk several blocks, Norah keeping a safe distance behind Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn opens the door to the building and disappears inside Norah follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn steps into an elevator. Norah does too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors close. Lynn slaps the `stop elevator' button. Norah emits a small yelp. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you following me? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not following you. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are following me! Lynn freezes for a moment. It seems she isn't even breath Her anger twists into fear. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you? Norah remains silent. Lynn paces back and forth. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LYNN Shit! This is not happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah is uncomfortable. Lynn spins around to face Norah. LYNN Listen, I'm sorry. I thought... I thought you were following me. NORAH That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn steps closer. LYNN You think I'm crazy. NORAH No. No I don't. LYNN I'm not crazy. NORAH It was a mistake. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn smiles. Norah releases the stop button. Nothing happ LYNN It's not moving. NORAH Let's press the alarm button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn shrugs. Norah presses the alarm button. There's a lo quick ring. They wait for something to happen. An awkward silence hangs in the air. Norah gives it anoth quick punch for good measure. Smiles. They look at the ceiling. They look at the floor. Norah makes little noise Norah takes out her sign language book. She steals a quic sideways look at Lynn before settling on the series of sm illustrated hands before her. LYNN Go to the university? NORAH Me? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn leans close and checks out the book.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobby... Lynn sizes Norah up. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this gorilla who knows sign language and I've always thought that would have to be the most amazing thing ever. You know? To actually talk to a gorilla. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've seen something on-- Norah nods. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KoKo. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, with the kitten. Norah offers a sad nod. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitten died. It wasn't KoKo's fault. She was heartbroken. A KNOCKING sound reverberates through the elevator. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of weird, don't you think? Teaching a gorilla to talk. Probably, gorillas aren't supposed to talk. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what's so cool about it. Lynn takes a long bold look at Norah. Norah sweats. The elevator moves. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry again about the... NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't... it's fine. Lynn lightly touches the crook of Norah's arm.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got nice veins. Norah smiles self consciously. She's flustered. Not a familiar sensation. The doors open to the "Albuquerque Bl Services." LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should give blood. Lynn steps off the elevator and grabs a white coat from a rack. She glances back with a smile just as the doors clo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is dark except for a TV in the living room and light in Norah's bedroom window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah pulls the photos from her bag and sets them on a sh next to the candy heart. Then, she drops to the floor and pulls the LUNCH BOX from under her bed. She surveys the contents: lipstick tipped cigarette butts eyelash curler, a Blue Jay feather, an old photo. In the photo two girls, twelve and five, stand with their mom. A cigarette dangles from the mother's ruby red mouth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time Rose's Sentra sits alone. No blue Camry in sigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose lies in bed and listens to cars go by on the highway She checks her watch, picks up the phone and dials. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Could you tell me what time you have? Okay. Thanks. Rose hangs up and falls back onto the bed, feet dangling the edge. She stares at the ceiling and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE I am strong. I am powerful. I am a winner. (pause) I'm a fucking idiot.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL HALLWAY- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Rose stands in the motel's glass enclosed hallway watchin the world go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe clears the dinner table while Oscar occupies himself markers, construction paper, and a creative impulse. Rose walks in defeated. JOE You're back early. ROSE I'm quitting real estate. JOE What are you talking about? You can't quit real estate. You're gonna be great at real estate. You got the whole look and besides, that's where everything's headed. Hell, it's what I should have done forty years ago. ROSE Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sits at the table next to Oscar. She looks miserable Oscar looks at his mom. OSCAR Want me to make you something happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose can't help but smile. ROSE Yeah. I'd like that. JOE Make me something happy too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose hands Winston a canister of Fancy Corn and a busines card. Rays of the sun dart off the edges of the card in a style of a child's drawing. It reads, "Sunshine Cleaning. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunshine Cleaning. Nice. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought we'd put a positive spin on things. My son drew the design.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Oscar stares at Winston's empty sleeve. WINSTON That's a nice job you did there. OSCAR Where's your arm? ROSE Oscar! WINSTON That's all right. ROSE I was thinking maybe I could set a few out by the register? WINSTON Yeah sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose hands Winston a stack of cards. He places them in an business card holder in front of several Clean Sweep busi cards. WINSTON This is great but you guys should really get out there and market yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar plays with an extraction cleaner and accidently tur it on. Winston gives him a nod that indicates that he sho turn it off. He does. ROSE So, marketing? Like...? WINSTON Funeral Homes, property managers... What you really want is to get in with the insurance companies. They can throw you a ton of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar walks into the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is jammed with model planes, cars and boats in various stages of construction. A hobbyist's fantasy land

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Oscar's mouth drops open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston puffs up a bit with `manly know how'. WINSTON Do you guys have your B.B.P. certification? ROSE B.B. who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston smiles. WINSTON Blood Born Pathogens. The big money jobs... they'll expect you to be certified. I can register you for the next seminar if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, Norah, Oscar and Joe follow SHERM LAWSON across the lot. Rose shoots an irritated look to her dad. ROSE (whispering to Norah) Did you ask him to come. NORAH Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe positions himself next to Rose. JOE (Quietly to Rose) Now Sherm's gonna say he's against the wall but don't you believe him. There's always some wiggle room. ROSE I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troop comes to a stop in front of a large blue van. SHERM I think you're gonna like this Econoline.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sherm opens the back doors. Rose, Joe and Sherm stick the heads inside. Rose nods. JOE The girls have started up their own specialized cleaning business. Crime scene and trauma clean-up. ROSE It's a real growth industry. SHERM Sounds kinda gory.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can be. Can be. Rose surveys the interior space. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta take any contaminated materials to the incinerators. So we'll need lots of space back here. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the bloody stuff. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how much is this? SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen Ninety-nine. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the play on that? SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's the floor right there. I'm actually taking a loss on this to make room for some new product. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I could pay cash. SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash is good. Sherm walks around and unlocks the driver's side door. JOE (whispering to Rose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him about the bumper. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dented bumper. Rose approaches Sherm with a smile. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed the bumper's kind of banged up. Sherm smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Character. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were over at Motor Mart on Lomas earlier. They got a nice looking Chevy G series for eighteen. SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power steering? Joe nods. Oscar crawls into the passenger seat for a closer look. H sees the CB mounted on the ceiling and tugs Norah's sleev OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, excellent. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, do people even use those anymore? OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Sherm grabs the handset to demonstrate. SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a CB. You talk into this thing and hold this thing down and it turns your voice into radio waves and sends it into the heavens. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven? Sherm tosses the keys to Rose.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take it for a test drive. Rose, Norah and Oscar pile into the van. Joe hangs back w Sherm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Econo van rumbles by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose drives. Norah sits shotgun and sings the baseline to 70s era porno. Oscar kneels between them staring at the C NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bow-chicka-bow-bow. Can I drive? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the CB! Rose reaches up and clicks the CB on. Nothing but static. adjusts the frequency dial until she lands on the faintes hint of a voice buried beneath the crush of static. Oscar's face lights up with amazement. Rose is under-whel She clicks the CB off. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antenna's probably broke. Norah points out the window. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice Cream Hut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pays for three soft serve cones and makes her way to picnic table where Norah and Oscar wait. Norah points to an `apartment for rent' sign on the build across the street. A big bosomed woman sits on the porch a rabbit in her lap. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How cool to live across from the Ice Cream Hut. Rose distributes the melty goods. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should rent it. Seriously, you're making money now. Norah assesses the building. The RABBIT LADY sees them staring. She waves. Rose and Norah turn around amused.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH Yeah well, what about Dad? ROSE Oh please, Dad would survive just fine. You should do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Norah thinks about a possible move glistening rivulets chocolate ice cream drip down Oscar's cone, over his hand on to Norah's leg. NORAH Ahh! Lick around the base. Secure the perimeter. (To Rose) Don't you teach this kid anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah demonstrates proper technique. She extends her tong out to the bottom edge of the dripping glob, then twirls cone to lick away the troublesome chocolate. LYNN (O.S.) It's the gorilla girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah looks up to see Lynn with a milk shake in hand. An involuntary smile breaks across Norah. LYNN You never came to donate. NORAH Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn looks at Rose. An awkward moment passes. NORAH My sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose smiles, nods a hi. Something familiar about the girl nags at Rose. She searches to connect a face out of conte Lynn eyes Norah. Chemistry. LYNN We have snacks you know. Juice boxes. NORAH Had I known about the juice boxes...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose makes the connection - her smile drops. Lynn picks u the tension between the two. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, see you around. Lynn leaves. Rose slaps Norah with an accusing look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands with Sherm and waits for the girls to return. looks at his watch. SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still selling that luggage? JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. That was a whole big mess. SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crappy zippers. Wasn't that it? Sherm smiles. Joe's smile disappears. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's been a while now. Dropped the luggage around the time your other lot when out of business. Touche. Sherm's smile dissolves. SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could maybe drop it to nineteen even. Joe holds out for more. SHERM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And toss in some wiper fluid. Joe smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, Norah and Oscar walk back to the van. Everyone's slightly stickier. Rose clenches her jaw. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH I just wanted to give her the pictures. ROSE You took the pictures? Why would you do that? We could get in a lot of trouble for that. NORAH Relax, I didn't give them to her.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: Joe sits in his Lazy Boy as Norah hauls a box from her ro NORAH It's just three blocks away. JOE I know.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH It's not like I'm never gonna see you. JOE Hey, I think you should have done this a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe strains to be cavalier but he can't look at Norah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A marquee welcomes the conference attendees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sits on a folding chair and takes notes. The thirty so people listening to the SPEAKER appear to be mostly hospital staff and EMT workers. A placard near the door reads: SEMINAR FOR BLOOD BORNE PATHOGENS. CARL SWANSON leans forward from his chair and looks down row to Rose. SPEAKER OK. Let's take a quick break before we move on to potential pathogens suspended in excrement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stands by a display of medical waste pamphlets and munches on a sandwich. As she takes a bite, Carl walks up CARL Food's better at the bar. (holding out his hand) Carl Swanson, Above and Beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flustered, Rose brushes crumbs off her face and inadverte deposits a blob of mustard on her cheek. They shake hands ROSE Rose- (swallow) Rose Lorkowski. Nice to meet you. CARL I hear you're my new competition.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE We're hardly competition for you. CARL (smiles) I'm glad to see you're doing a little homework. A lot of people, you know, they think they can just jump in to this, make lots of money. But, they don't know what they're doing. No idea. They're not professional and that makes us all look bad. ROSE Well, we're not like that. I just have to complete this seminar and we're certified. CARL You're not certified? ROSE Not yet. Probably by the end of the month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl smiles, dips a napkin in his cup of water and wipes smudge of mustard from Rose's cheek. CARL You had a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attendees file back to their chairs. ROSE I think it's starting. CARL Sure I can't buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Carl sit at the bar nursing drinks. CARL If you spray the enzyme at that point it'll just turn back to liquid which is a pain in the ass. The key is to bag it when it's kind of Jell-o-ee.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE That makes total sense. Why didn't I think of that? CARL You just figure all this shit out as you go. Experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose chews on her cocktail straw. ROSE It's not how I thought it'd be. I thought it'd be gross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stops. Reflects. Turns to Carl. ROSE Sometimes it's gross. The maggots are gross. The maggots kind of freak me. CARL Yeah. ROSE The sound. The munching sound. CARL And it's so hard to kill the little fuckers. ROSE Tell me about it. You pour industrial bleach right on `em...nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl offers a knowing nod. CARL Just roll their eyes and call you a pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose laughs and takes another sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the bathroom is open. Carl hums a happy tune the shower. Rose shimmies back into her clothes with an expression of self-loathing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE I am strong. I am powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose drives and Norah holds a long list of funeral homes other establishments. They're all crossed off. Oscar sits bored in the back. OSCAR What's a bastard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks at Norah with concern. OSCAR Jeremy said I was a bastard. What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose has no idea how to respond. Norah turns to face Osca NORAH It just means your mom wasn't married when she had you. It's no big deal. In a couple of years you're gonna find it's a free pass to cool. You'll probably start a band called Bastard Son. Use it to impress the chicks. Trust me, the whole bastard thing... it's working for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar looks to Rose and then back to Norah. Rose's phone rings. She answers it, relieved for the distraction ROSE Hello, Sunshine Cleaning... Well, I'm glad you liked the Fancy Corn....Okay, yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose grabs a pen, hands it to Norah and motions for her t write something down. ROSE Okay... 2327 Grove Avenue. Got it... Sure. Yeah. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH What was that? ROSE A suicide!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls the van up to the house and sees the old lady sitting out front. MRS. DAVIS. ROSE Oh, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah exchange a look and then Rose turns to Osc ROSE OK. Stay in the van. You want a soda or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar shakes his head. ROSE We won't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rose and Norah get out and unload supplies the old lad stands to greet them. She's dressed up in the way old lad are when they expect company. ROSE Mrs. Davis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman nods. She is dazed with grief. ROSE We're the cleaning service. MRS. DAVIS Yes, yes. I... I wanted to give you the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old woman holds out a shaky hand. Rose gently takes t keys. Norah hangs back. MRS. DAVIS In the sunroom. That's where my husband... I had bridge and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blinks twice, slowly, then snaps back.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MRS. DAVIS Do you need me to show you? ROSE No, no. I think we can find it. MRS. DAVIS Oh. Okay. That's good then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah gather their things and head up the stairs MRS. DAVIS My son-in-law's coming to take me to lunch at the Howard Johnson's. They have such nice rolls there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose hands Norah the key and motions for her to go ahead. ROSE Would you like to sit for a moment, Mrs. Davis? MRS. DAVIS Yes dear, I think I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sits down on the steps with Mrs. Davis and Norah qui enters the house. From the van Oscar watches Rose and the old woman sit sid side on the front step. Rose's hand rests lightly on the woman's bony shoulder. Words seem useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah looks around the room furnished modestly with a mix of antiques and things that are simply old. Yellow sticky notes cling to doors, walls, light switches etc. Each note contains a simple instruction such as `tur off light' or `watch news at 6:00'. Norah walks past family photos that line the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah enters the red splattered room. A walker lies on it side next to a blood-soaked rug. Golden sunlight pours through the windows.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A yellow square sticks to a picture frame on the coffee table. The frame holds the image of a smiling young coupl a different era. The note reads `Edna plays bridge at 4:0 Norah slips a Tyvec jumper on and looks out the window. A pull up to the curb. Norah stops and watches her sister w Mrs. Davis to the car before starting her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose enters quietly, in a fog. The stillness of grief is contagious. NORAH She okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose nods and picks up the photo of a younger Mr and Mrs Davis. She then steps into her Tyvec coveralls and zips u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah drives. Rose holds Oscar in her lap, arms clasped t around him. OSCAR That lady seemed really sad. ROSE Her husband died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar thinks about this a moment. OSCAR So he's in heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose nods. OSCAR Maybe we could let her use our CB and she could talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks confused. Oscar presses on. OSCAR Maybe he would hear her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose smiles. Doesn't seem like the moment to correct him. ROSE Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They ride the rest of the way home in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's Monte Carlo sits out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar and Joe scratch game cards. OSCAR I won a million dollars! JOE Let me see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar hands the ticket over. JOE You gotta get two hydrants with a matching amount. See? None of your fire hydrants match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar looks at the Lucky Dog card with defeat. JOE And three zeros is a thousand dollars. You woulda won a thousand dollars but it doesn't match anything. OSCAR What happens if it doesn't match anything? JOE You toss it and try the next one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar moves on to his next ticket. He scratches the coati away and tentatively lifts his game card OSCAR I think I won five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe looks at the card. He looks at Oscar and grins. OSCAR I'm gonna buy a trampoline and a karaoke player and some chocolate honey dipped donuts.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE Whoa now. Hold up there kiddo. That's not your money. That's my money. OSCAR I scratched it. JOE Yes you did. You scratched the ticket that I bought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar follows his grampa over to the pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're not going to spend the money. We're going to invest the money. Joe plunks in some quarters, dials, waits while it rings. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, that's the difference between a regular person and somebody with business acumen. That's a good word for you to know. A-cu-men. Means smarts. Oscar nods and sips his Coke. JOE (into the receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby! Joe Lorkowski here. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I'd call. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well, I got the money and we're in. But you gotta throw in twenty bags of ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pays bills at the kitchen table. Oscar bounces a sup ball. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna make the money grow because that's the smart way. It's capital and you don't spend that. You invest it. That way you can get the SP250 and have money left over. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Oscar races out of the kitchen and then races back in wit pamphlet showcasing the amazingly sleek SP250 binoculars. hands the pamphlet to Rose. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The binoculars that grampa's gonna get me for my birthday. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OSCAR (cont'd) They've got an internal stabilizer thingy that's electronic so if you're in a speed boat or something it won't matter and...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh honey, come here. Rose pulls out a chair for Oscar. Oscar sits down and cro his arms in front of himself. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes your grampa promises things that he really wants to happen. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's really gonna get `em. He's got a plan. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. If you say so. Rose goes back to the bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn wears a white coat. Norah sits in one of the reclini chairs scattered about the room. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made it seem so fun. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
