dialogues.text: Oh it is fun. Would you like a refreshment? Norah smiles and shakes her head. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Norah watches Lynn's hands push up her sleeve. Lynn rubs iodine in expanding circles on the inside of Norah's arm. Lynn puts plastic gloves on and ties a tourniquet around Norah's arm. She puts a rubber ball in Norah's hand. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you squeeze that for me? Norah squeezes the ball and Lynn touches the plump vein. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. One more time.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lynn takes the needle and draws it close to Norah's arm. NORAH Oh my God, is that the needle? It's a fucking cocktail straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah looks nervous. Lynn smiles reassuringly. LYNN Trust me, I'm very good at this. Squeeze again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah squeezes, Lynn touches the soft blue stripe of bloo beneath Norah's skin and slides the needle into the vein. LYNN Wasn't that fun? NORAH You might have oversold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn smiles. LYNN Kind of twirl the ball around in your hand. Good. It doesn't hurt, does it? NORAH (shakes her head) Feels hot. LYNN That's a good sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah self-consciously nods and smiles. Lynn turns and jostles the bag of blood. NORAH My friend's having a thing tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn switches her attention from the blood back to Norah. NORAH Never mind. LYNN What? NORAH Nothing it's...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't like it. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music and party-goers spill from the student ghetto house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah and Lynn sit on a ratty couch in a crowded smoke fi room. Next to them, a flannel wearing burn-out rocks to headphones. Norah wears a candy necklace. Debauchery play out around them. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you wouldn't have any fun here. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am having fun. Norah takes a tug on the joint and passes it to Lynn. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambs breath. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no thanks. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight edge? LYNN (Shakes head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kind of superstitious. Norah nods and passes the joint across Lynn to the burn-o The burn-out tugs and passes it back to Lynn. Lynn waves off a second time.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH She's Mormon. LYNN I'm not Mormon. I just... You're gonna think it's weird. NORAH What? LYNN Sometimes I think that when you get high or drink or alter your consciousness like that-- NORAH You don't drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn shakes her head. LYNN I think it weakens you psychically... like it creates these cracks and then bad things can seep in and maybe never go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah stares at Lynn with great blood-shot concentration. NORAH All right, you're kind of freakin me out. LYNN Sorry. NORAH You should just tell people you're Mormon. LYNN I think your boyfriend is winning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two women gnaw at Randy's neck. His necklace is almost em NORAH Yes. Yes, he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn lightly tugs on Norah's candy necklace. She leans in close and takes a bite of the candy. Norah catches her breath. Paralyzed. Lynn smiles, pleased by Norah's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LYNN (whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe. Norah snaps back. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need more beer. Norah pulls herself off the couch and starts for the keg. stops. Turns. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um. Can I get you anything? LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good. Norah offers a nervous smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah and Randy lie on a thread bare couch. Their bodies to the motion of sex. Norah's thoughts are elsewhere. A small TV sits next to Norah's growing collection of fou trinkets. It spills blue light into the smoke tinged air. On the TV, a REPORTER stands outside Quicky Lube. Norah t her attention to the TV while Randy pumps and grinds. She grabs the remote. REPORTER (on TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tragedy today when an out of control driver crashed his car into a south side Quicky Lube killing one employee. RANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh. Norah turns up the volume. Randy grinds to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: REPORTER The driver of the automobile, apparently suffered a heart attack at the wheel and is currently in critical condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Randy glares at Norah. Norah answers. NORAH Hello. RANDY Unbelievable. NORAH (into phone) Yeah, I'm watching it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A van zooms past with a SUNSHINE CLEANING MAGNET on the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy steps out onto the porch where the big bosomed RABB LADY strokes her rabbit. He closes the door behind him. RANDY Hey. RABBIT LADY Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy starts down the steps feeling dejected. RABBIT LADY You like rabbits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy stops and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large glass panel that made up the front of the store shattered. Shards dangle from red tipped edges. Blood and glass mingle on the linoleum floor and plastic chairs. Outside, Mac motions a stunned crowd to disperse. Rose an Norah walk confidently past Mac into the lobby where a ma wearing a Quick Lube shirt stands off to the side and cri

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mac watches as Rose goes back inside and greets the offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OFFICER points to the shattered glass. OFFICER Nut job goes through the window there. (he stops, turns) You guys are BBP Certified, right? ROSE Legally, it's not really necessary. NORAH We are. ROSE We're in the process. NORAH You went to that thing. ROSE We adhere to all the proper procedures when dealing with a potentially hazardous situation. We are very professional. NORAH Wait. I thought you went to that thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose scans the area. ROSE Are you guys all finished? OFFICER It's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah slip into their Tyvecs. ROSE Why don't you grab the wet-vac and I'll start bagging the loose stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer walks past Mac who continues to stare at Rose She looks beautiful and strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah pull supplies from the van and ready themselves for the Quicky Lube job. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you went to the thing. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I mean, I went to part of it. Most of it. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean you went to part of it? It was a one day thing. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got side tracked. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Side tracked? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Above and Beyond guy was there. Carl. We got talking shop and-- NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, you humped Carl! Rose can't deny it. Norah shakes her head. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already registered for the next one. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Oscar sit in the car pulled off to the side of a lonely highway intersection. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got twenty bucks and you want three pizza's. They cost five dollars each and you have a coupon for two dollars off. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE (cont'd) You figure you'll tip the delivery guy a couple bucks but the delivery guy turns out to be a lady. Real sizzler. So you give her a crisp five. How much do you have left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar thinks. Joe assumes there's no way the kid's getting this and tur his attention outside. A truck appear on the horizon. OSCAR Two dollars? JOE Hey, how'd you come up with that? OSCAR Math.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck slows down as it reaches the intersection, pull off the road, and stops. Joe gets out and walks over. Oscar watches the trucker hop down from the cab and shake Joe's hand like they're old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk of the Monte Carlo brims with shrimp and ice. J slams it closed, climbs in the car and gives Oscar a wink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monte Carlo slices through a vast empty landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe beams with excitement. JOE The thing is Oscar...and this is important to learn early...life is sales. Buying and selling. It's the core of social interaction. And human beings are social beings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke starts to seep out from under the hood. Joe eyes th temperature gauge.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE No, no, no, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah loads equipment into the van, gets in and waits for Rose to finish the transaction. A MIDDLE AGED WOMAN opens the door. She's angry.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE I'm sorry, I don't mean to bother you. I just wanted to let you know that we're all finished up and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman glares at Rose. MIDDLE AGED WOMAN Oh, you want to get paid. ROSE We can come back later if that's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman shakes her head and holds out a check. MIDDLE AGED WOMAN I can't believe I have to deal with this now. My son just died for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman looks away. ROSE I'm so sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose starts to leave. MIDDLE AGED WOMAN Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stops. Turns MIDDLE AGED WOMAN For what you did. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose nods and continues on to the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride down an Albuquerque street in silence. ROSE You want a Coke? NORAH Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose fills a cup at the soda fountain. Through the window sees Mac and family pull up on the other side of the stor Mac gets out and pumps gas. The woman, HEATHER, laughs wi the little girl in the back seat. They look happy. Rose's fountain drink overflows. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit. Rose grabs for a napkin which clumps and tears. The door BEEPS. Rose jumps behind the candy rack and peek around. All clear. She turns and smacks into Heather. Hea glares at Rose. HEATHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I don't know? Heather trembles with anger. Rose stands frozen. HEATHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have been hot shit in high school but what are you now? Nothing. A waste of space. Heather reaches out and gives Rose a little push. Ten yea of anger culminating in this one anti climactic gesture. Rose watches Heather walk away and knows every word is tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stream of water leaks from the trunk. Joe gets out curs under his breath. He kicks the car and a hub cap falls of It's an unbearable insult. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid shit heap! Fifty years of failures result in an explosion of frustration. Joe stomps on the hub cap, picks it up and throws it as far as he can. Joe gathers himself and leans in the window. He forces a smile at Oscar. Oscar looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE It's alright. Everything's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe opens the trunk and checks on the shrimp. A car zooms Joe tries to wave it down. No good. Another zooms by. JOE Come on, come on, come on, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe struggles to wave down a car. No luck. Joe has an ide JOE Make like you're crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar turns on the tears. A car stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose walks in. Oscar and Joe feign casualness. Joe looks at the bathroom door which stands open. Inside tub brims with shrimp and ice. ROSE What did you guys do today? OSCAR Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose turns to Joe who shrugs. ROSE How's it without Norah here? JOE Weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks over and casually shuts the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy stuffs his face with a hotdog while Norah glares, annoyed. RANDY I'm sorry. I know it was stupid. NORAH On so many levels.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RANDY I'm really sorry. I swear it won't happen again. It's just... you weren't around and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah shakes her head. Randy doesn't know what to say. NORAH Listen, Randy I think we should stop hanging out. RANDY You're breaking up with me over the rabbit lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah doesn't respond. RANDY I don't know, the way you act, I didn't even think that you'd care that much. NORAH Yeah, I don't. I should, but I don't. And you're a really great guy. But...I don't care if you have sex with the rabbit lady... and I mean, it seems like I should care about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose opens a stack of neglected mail. She is interrupted light knock on the door. Rose peeks out the peep hole. ROSE Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose hesitates, then opens the door just a crack. MAC Rose. ROSE What are you doing here? MAC Can we talk a minute? ROSE Oscar's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose stands her ground for a moment before stepping outsi MAC It was great seeing you last night. You looked so professional and confident. Your own business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac touches her lightly on the arm. ROSE How's the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac looks away. MAC I just wanted to congratulate you on the business. Seems like things are really going great for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Mac's eyes meet.      Rose smiles. ROSE They are. If we keep going at this rate I can hire a couple of employees soon, put a little more in marketing, give those Clean Sweep guys a run for their money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose glows. ROSE I'm a business woman. MAC (nodding) You're a business woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah stands disheveled, six pack in hand. Lynn opens the door wearing slippers. NORAH Ever been trestling?

dialogues.speaker: EXT NOB HILL RESTAURANT ROW
dialogues.text: Shrimp jiggles in Joe's hand cart as he makes his way tow the row of upscale restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A couple of upscale hipsters stare curiously at the hand as they pass Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds of sex seep through thin walls. Oscar sits up in b After a moment he crawls out of bed, he grabs a flashligh from his shelf and exits his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mattress squeaks slightly as Mac and Rose have sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In pajamas and bare feet, Oscar steps into the night. He flicks on the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah leads Lynn through a wooded area toward a train trestle. Norah carries the two remaining beers of a six p LYNN Are the bodies there? NORAH No. The person is gone. It's weird `cuz we're connected to them in this strangely intimate way... but we never actually meet them. It's just kind of weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah steps over a discarded tire. NORAH I have seen a dead body once though. LYNN Yeah? NORAH My mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn follows Norah, not knowing how to respond. It's awkw Norah tries to lighten things.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH She was in a movie of the week once, ya know.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LYNN Your mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah nods. NORAH A bunch of Hollywood people were filming down in Old Town. They thought my mom was so beautiful and so talented that they gave her a speaking part. You want to hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn nods. NORAH `I recommend the pecan pie.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah looks back at Lynn for applause. LYNN I recommend the pecan pie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah nods. NORAH That was her line. It was on TV and everything. LYNN That's pretty cool. NORAH Me and Rose, we didn't actually see it but Rose says mom talked about it all the time. I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah shrugs. NORAH I don't remember her much at all. I have this box of her stuff though, little things she touched. When it seems like she never even really existed... it's proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two reach the bottom of a train trestle. NORAH All right. This is where we climb. LYNN What?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to that girder. Norah points to a rusted girder about eight feet from the underbelly of the track. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not climbing up there. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best place to be when it comes. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. Norah slips her hand through one of the plastic rings of six pack and starts to climb. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna miss the best part. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I accept that. The two cans of beer dangle from Norah's arm like a giant charm bracelet and clank against girders as she climbs. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like... it's like this big pissed off God up in your face just screaming at you. So close you can smell the metal on his breath. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds great. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. I'm telling you. Norah wedges her butt into the belly of a beam and taps h fingers against the rusted girder. After a moment she lea out and looks down toward Lynn. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to bum you out with the whole mom stuff. I just thought you would... I don't know, I guess I thought... LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The trestle starts to shake. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming. The thunder gets louder. Lynn covers her ears. Norah pops open a beer and laughs as the train approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar walks along the sidewalk alone. He stops at the van opens the door and gets in. He looks very small in the driver's seat. He lifts the handset to the CB.

dialogues.speaker: DIALOGUE WITH FOLLOWING SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I before I was born? What happens when we die? Do animals go to the same place as we go after we die? Is heaven really crowded? When somebody gets an arm chopped off does it go to heaven? Is Jesus another name for you or are you two separate people? Were you born? Will you die? If you already live in heaven where do you go when you die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train careens above Norah. Sparks fly from the blur o wheels. The sky flashes between each of the cars. Stars a grease and metal and night collide. Norah closes her eyes The sound of the train merges with the loud static of a C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is an electric blue. The kind that lives in memor and dreams. Rose (10) and Norah (5) play in a parked car. Rose pretends to drive and smoke a cigarette while Norah makes faces in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose gets out of the car and races toward the house. Nora chases after. NORAH Rose, wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giggling Rose stumbles in. She stops. The bathroom door open slightly. She walks over peeks through the opening. There's a dress crumpled on the floor. A woman slumps motionless in the tub. Her delicate hand hangs over the e Scarlet fingerprints mar the white porcelain. Norah enters the front door. She smiles, unburdened by th knowledge. She runs towards Rose. Rose quickly pushes her back and closes the door. Norah senses something's wrong. She struggles to see what behind the door but Rose won't let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The static mixes back into the roar of the train. The roa grows distant and is replaced by Norah's laughter. Still laughing, Norah takes a sip of her beer and sets it a beam next to her. The beer falls. Norah tries to catch loses her balance and falls with a thud. Lynn catches her breath. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Lynn runs over to find Norah on her back, eyes closed. No opens her eyes and laughs. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You idiot. Norah grabs the beer that she had been chasing. There's n much left but she downs the remainder. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sneaky fucker.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LYNN That was really stupid. NORAH I think I broke my hand. LYNN Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn leans close with real concern. NORAH No. But it hurts like a mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn pops the top on the remaining beer and takes a huge before handing it to Norah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar walks down the sidewalk alone. His flashlight provi small circle of light on the cement in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stands in her T-shirt and undies. Mac shuts the door Rose leans her head against the door and exhales deeply. turns as if something is calling her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stands on tip toes and feels around on top of the refrigerator until she finds what she's looking for... emergency cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sits down on the couch and lights her cigarette. The nicotine patch is still clearly visible on her arm. Rose looks at the stack of unopened mail. Something grabs attention. An envelope bearing the return address of Paul Datzman-Mead. Rose rips opens the envelope. Rose stares at an invitation to Paula's baby shower. A sm creeps across her face. The front door opens and Oscar walks in.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brow furrowed, he walks past Rose without acknowledging h He goes straight to his room and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bottle of wine sits empty on a box next to two nearly e Styrofoam cups. LYNN How's the hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah shakes the last few drops from her cup and starts gnawing on the side. Lynn takes Norah's hand and examines NORAH Ow! LYNN Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn draws Norah's hand close to her lips. Smiles. Looks Norah. Norah's a deer in headlights. Lynn kisses Norah's hand. Everything is still and tense. LYNN Better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah   stares at her recently kissed hand and nods. She up to   Lynn. Lynn kisses Norah lightly on the lips. A te kiss.   Then again. Softly. Norah doesn't move, eyes lock Lynn.   All is good. Norah leans in and kisses Lynn's neck. Lynn's eyes are cl enjoying the moment. Lynn opens her eyes. The school photos of Lynn sit direct across from her on the shelf. Lynn stares at the pictures Waves of recognition and confusion register in her eyes. Norah kisses Lynn's neck oblivious. LYNN Is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn pulls away. LYNN Are those...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lynn tries to suss it out, shakes her head, looks at Nora LYNN How do you have my school pictures? NORAH I just... I found them. I was gonna tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn shakes her head disbelieving. LYNN Where would you find old pictures of me? NORAH At work. LYNN What? NORAH We did this job a while back. This woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn scans the other trinkets arranged neatly on the shel Her eyes focus on the photo ID. Her mother. Her face goes completely blank. Shock. LYNN My mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah bites her lip and nods. LYNN My mom is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hazy mix of shame, sadness and guilt seeps into the voi NORAH I wanted to tell you... that first day. That's why I-- LYNN You knew this whole time? NORAH I think... You know, I think there's a reason that I found them. The pictures. Because that lead me to you, right? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't know exactly what went on between you and your mom... what the situation was... but it just seems like... You know, of anybody, I would understand. Lynn's hazy emotional mix has hardened into something sha Anger. She looks at Norah with disgust. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would understand? Lynn turns to leave. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Please. Don't...I-- Lynn opens the door. Norah reaches out but Lynn stops her with an icy look. LYNN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sick, you know that? There's something wrong with you. Lynn shuts the door and it feels like a slap. Norah sinks down onto the couch. Just Norah now. The emptiness crowds around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The afternoon sun beats against the weathered paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby shower invitation looms large on the makeup tabl Rose wears a slip and unusually big hair. She grabs sever outfits from her closet. Oscar watches. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blue or the flowery? OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blue. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good call. Rose slips on the dress and sits to apply mascara. Oscar shuffles out of the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose's cell phone rings. She picks up the phone while applying lipstick. ROSE Sunshine Cleaning. INSURANCE GUY (over phone) Hello, this is Henry Schmidt at State Farm. ROSE State Farm? (pause) State Farm! Yes. Hello. INSURANCE GUY (over phone) I spoke with you about a month ago. ROSE Yes! Hi. What can I do for you? INSURANCE GUY (over phone) We've got a house we need to turn around and our regular guys are busy in Santa Fe today. Thought I'd give you all a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose knocks over a bottle of nail polish remover as she g a pen and writes down the info. ROSE Great. No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose hangs up. ROSE Shit, shit, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls on some panty hose and wrestles with her shoes ROSE Honey, call grampa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar dials. OSCAR It's busy.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose grabs her purse. Rose and Oscar rush out. A baby sho gift sits forgotten by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah cradles a phone to her ear and shoves clothes from box into an old dresser. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blow off the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose drives the van and talks on her cell phone. Oscar lo tiny in the passenger seat. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't I... I RSVPed.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE CONVERSATION
dialogues.text: NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell him we can't do it. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an insurance company. They could throw us a ton of work. This is our in. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, don't go to the damn baby shower. It's not like you ever even liked Paula. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise I'll come straight after the shower and help finish up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Oscar walk up to the house. Rose tries the door it's locked. She knocks. No answer. An uneasy tension sho through her. She fumbles for her keys to unlock the door and is hit wi horrible familiar smell. Oscar pinches his nose.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OSCAR Pee-ew. ROSE Stay out here. OSCAR Why do I--

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE (too sternly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I said so. Angry, Oscar sits down on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone next to Joe's Lazy Boy is off the hook. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Rose walks briskly through the house. Urgency mounts with each step. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Daddy! Rose throws the bathroom door open in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe scoops rotten shrimp from the bathtub with an empty f corn canister and dumps them into a garbage can. Rose recoils at the intense smell. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm busy here. He tries to swing the door shut but Rose stops it. Steps ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it dad, you scared me. Sweat drips down Joe's face. He continues his labor and avoids looking at Rose. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those snotty restaurant fucks wouldn't buy my shrimp. Some bullshit about health codes or whatever. I don't believe that shit for a second. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, dad what were you-- He holds up a finger.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE Don't. Don't start with me. (Pause) Bastards completely shut me out. They got their own little cartel. Little restaurant mafia. I bet they screwed with my car too. I wouldn't put it past `em. Bunch of shady mother fuckers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose leans against the door and watches her father. A wet slap punctuates each new deposit into the garbage. ROSE I need you to watch Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another load of slimy shrimp smacks the garbage. JOE I can't. ROSE What do you mean you can't? JOE I can't watch Oscar today Rose. ROSE I'm in a real bind here. JOE Yeah, well it's hard, isn't it? Raising a kid on your own. Try two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Oscar get out of the Sentra and march toward the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston sees Rose and Oscar through the window and return his attention to the model plane before him. Rose and Oscar enter. WINSTON You look nice.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston finishes gluing the piece and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering if Oscar could hang out here for a little while. Winston looks nervous. He looks at Oscar. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got this baby shower to go to and Norah's working a job and my dad's incapacitated... Do you mind? WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lifesaver. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did your hair different. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it? Winston nods. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Be good. I'll pick him up in a few hours when I'm done. Rose leaves. Oscar and Winston are left on their own. Win forces a smile. Oscar does not reciprocate. Winston turns walks to the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston glues a tiny piece to the model plane. Oscar inch his way over. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a World War Two Mitchell Cannon Nose Bomber. Oscar leans in closer to examine all the tiny pieces. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make all these models? Winston nods and points to a teeny plastic strut.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WINSTON Dab the end of that in the glue. Just a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar carefully dabs the plastic piece in the puddle of g and hands it to Winston. OSCAR What's that piece for? WINSTON It's a strut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With delicate precision, Winston attaches the piece. OSCAR What's a strut? WINSTON Supports the wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar examines one of the many completed models. OSCAR Seems like it'd be hard to build models with just one hand. WINSTON It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah drives the van down a desert road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls the Nissan in. She checks her lipstick in the rearview mirror before getting out and heading to the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah pulls supplies from the van and lugs them to the ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah grabs a bottle of OJ from the fridge, checks the expiration and takes a slug. Cat bowls sit in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norah examines a snapshot on the fridge. A chubby middle- woman surrounded by cats. The woman is bald and smiling. Norah spots some incense. She holds a stick to her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah lights the incense stick and sets it on the dresser next to a little statue of the laughing Buddha. A collect of cat whiskers sits in the Buddha's lap. Evidence of death soils the bed. Books crowd the night st Living with Breast Cancer, Foods That Fight Cancer, and Coming to Terms With Death.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norah rolls out plastic sheeting and prepares the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room titters with wannabe country clubbers. They nibb appetizers around a pastel tower of gifts. Rose lifts a cheese puff to her mouth. She's flanked by P and a MOUSEY WOMAN in a pink dress and matching pink pump MOUSEY So Rose, what are you doing? Are you still cleaning houses? PAULA Rose has gone into real estate. MOUSEY Really? ROSE Actually, I own my own business. MOUSEY A real estate business? ROSE No. It's a biohazard removal and crime scene clean up service. It's a growth niche industry right now В­ highly technical and competitive. MOUSEY What does that mean В­ biohazard removal whatever? ROSE A lot of times, when somebody dies, it can be kind of, you know, messy. So, we go in and clean up all that left over mess. Make sure that the area is clean and sanitary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula and Mousy exchange a glance infused with disgust. ROSE People just don't understand the health and safety risks involved in disposing of biological material like blood and body fluids.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAULA Oh my God. ROSE Course, we have a whole arsenal of disinfectants and um... professional techniques. Like I said, it's a highly technical and professional operation with a whole complicated, you know... methodology behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased with herself, Rose grabs another cheese puff. ROSE Real growth industry. MOUSEY I can't imagine. You like doing it? ROSE Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stops. She hadn't thought about whether she liked it ROSE I do. We come into the lives of people who have just experienced something so sad and profound. They've lost somebody. The circumstances are different but that's the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rose talks, her whole demeanor changes. Relaxes. That brittle, self conscious edge dissipates. ROSE And we help them. In this one small way... we help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is lost in her thoughts. Something profound is shift MOUSEY Sounds horrible to me. PAULA I believe I'd vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah stuffs bedding in biohazard bags and wraps the matt in plastic sheeting. A fan clanks at the window.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norah struggles to get the wrapped mattress though the do It tips and Norah bangs her hand against the door frame. NORAH Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incense falls from the dresser. Norah finally muscles mattress through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah drags the mattress to the driveway. A wisp of smoke curls from the window behind her. As Norah rubs her injured hand, she hears the teeniest ME rise from the bushes. She investigates. A little orange fluff ball at the base of some box hedges looks up with big startled eyes. Norah smiles. NORAH Oh my God, you're the cutest thing ever. Did you get left behind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitten answers with a pitiful raspy sound that passes a meow. Norah is powerless to resist. NORAH It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Norah leans down to pick up the kitten, it darts from bushes and heads toward the road. NORAH No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah chases the frightened kitty across the street and disappears behind a house. After a moment, Norah emerges from behind the house. She at the small kitten cradled in her arms, then looks up. A expression of horror and disbelief sweep over her. Norah runs toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PEPPY WOMAN with the enthusiasm of a game show contesta stands on a stool and waves her arms.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PEPPY Okay, ladies. For our first game we've taken five different kinds of candy bars and melted them in these diapers. MOUSEY Oh I love this game. PEPPY You all can--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere a cell phone rings. The peppy woman stops and l at Rose. Rose digs into her purse and pulls out the offen phone. She checks caller ID. It's Norah. She cuts it off. ROSE Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose forces a smile at Peppy who motions for someone to s distributing the diapers. PEPPY You can look, smell and taste. The first to identify all five correctly wins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flames shoot up around the dresser and gobble a curtain. Norah slaps a towel at the flames with one hand and holds phone with the other. ROSE (over the phone) Hello, you've reached Sunshine Cleaning. You're call is very important to us so... NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah snaps the phone shut and continues slapping back th flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose watches with a detached expression as Floral clad wo stick their noses in the brown goo of the diapers.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It hits Rose that she does not belong here. And for the f time, she does not want to belong here. She turns to Paul ROSE You know what? I... uh...Actually, there's somewhere I need to be. PAULA Oh nooo! You can't leave now. We're just starting the games. ROSE Yeah. Well... (smiles and nods) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stands and weaves her way through the throng of Step moms. Relief sweeps across her face as she nears the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose drives as the sun sinks into the desert landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls up near the fire trucks and still smoldering house. Rose steps from the car with an expression of horr Fear grips her as she scans the area for her sister. Then sees Norah, sitting in the van across the street. Headpho on. Kitten curled up in her lap. Rose marches over but Norah doesn't notice her until she on the window. Norah pulls off her headphones, opens the and slides out of the van. NORAH It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose's mouth slackens as her mind stumbles over the proba consequences of the scene before her. ROSE Oh my God, what have you done? NORAH It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE How does this happen? Huh? How do you burn down a house, Norah? Jesus fucking Christ! NORAH Jesus Rose, Calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose throws her keys at Norah. Norah turns to shield the kitten. The keys thump her arm. Norah eyes her sister. So that's how it's gonna be. NORAH Well, if you had been here to help me but no, you're off desperately trying to impress stupid high school people who don't even matter. Prove to your old cheerleading squad that you're not this huge loser. If you had been here doing your job it wouldn't have happened. So don't try to put all this on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah's denial of responsibility knocks the wind from Ros ROSE This is on you. You did this. You set a fucking house on fire! You. NORAH Oh, go ahead and play the martyr. It's like your favorite thing. ROSE I can't believe I was so stupid to think that you could handle a little bit of responsibility. NORAH I am   so sick of all your holier than   thou bullshit. Why don't you take   a look at you're own life, huh?   You're a real inspiration. ROSE Well maybe if I didn't have to take care of everybody in this family.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. I'm done being your excuse. Norah, filthy with soot, turns and walks away from Rose, fire and everything. The kitten clings to her shirt. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's great. Turn everything to shit and then walk away. Without turning or breaking her stride, Norah flips off R Rose leans down and picks up her keys, then turns and wat the firemen hose down the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, looking worse for wear, tries to open the door but store is closed and the door is locked. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. She bangs on the glass doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston walks from the back room and opens the door. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long baby shower. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I... everything's horrible. Rose is about to break. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar's asleep in back. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah's ruined everything. She burnt down a house. A client's house.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WINSTON Yeah. ROSE You know? WINSTON Carl told me. ROSE How does he...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Realization slaps. ROSE That's just great. We burnt down a client's house. How do you get around that? WINSTON Insurance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose shrugs. ROSE I figured we'd wait and get the better rate once I got certified. WINSTON Didn't you go to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose doesn't respond. She slowly blinks and lets her new reality ooze over her. ROSE There's not a lot I'm really good at, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston looks at Rose.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. I'm good at getting guys to want me. Not date or marry me. But want me. I've always been good at that. Winston looks away. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cheering. I was pretty good at that too. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheering is good. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Not as marketable as you'd think. Winston smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke slinks from a cigarette on the makeshift ashtray. Rose looks up to see Oscar in his PJs, one arm tucked in shirt, the sleeve dangling empty. Rose musters a smile. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brush your teeth? Oscar nods, kisses her good night. Rose watches him walk his room and takes a drag from her cigarette. There's a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks through the peep hole and sees Mac fidgeting outside. She takes a step from the door and freezes. Mac knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac looks at the unresponsive door with irritation. He sh his weight and jangles some change in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose leans against the wall with eyes closed. MAC (O.S.) Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a breath, opens her eyes, then opens the door. MAC Hey beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac smiles for the both of them. MAC I was starting to think you were on a date or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks at him like he's speaking a foreign language. MAC You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose nods. ROSE Long day. MAC Can I come in? ROSE It's not really a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac sags a bit. Then rallies. Flexes an eyebrow. MAC I got you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac pulls a small gold box from his pocket and presents i Rose. The top is engraved with her initials. MAC It's for your business cards. You put `em in there and, I don't know... impress people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs at the silliness of the whole concept. ROSE It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose stares at the small shiny box. It seems to make her MAC You don't like it? ROSE No, I like it very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks up and Mac senses something bad is coming his ROSE It's just this thing we're doing. MAC Come on, let's not do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Rose is resolute. She looks Mac in the eye. ROSE I don't want this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disbelief gives way to the unpleasant understanding. MAC So that's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose gives an almost imperceptible nod. Mac tries hard to ignore the rising slurry of hurt and anger. MAC That's it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac hesitates, hoping for a last minute reprieve. Finally nods and Rose watches him walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah steps off the elevator. People in white coats walk her, bump into her. Norah spots Lynn. Lynn sees Norah and looks away. GUY IN WHITE COAT (O.S.) Is this your first time donating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah turns to the GUY IN THE WHITE COAT addressing her. holds a clipboard. NORAH No.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GUY IN WHITE COAT Can I get your name? NORAH I need to talk to Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn approaches. LYNN She can't donate. You can't donate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to a sign indicating how often people can dona LYNN Forty-eight days. It's not been forty-eight days. NORAH Why are you acting like this? Why haven't you called me back. LYNN Listen, I just, don't think you're the kind of person I need to be hanging out with right now. NORAH What's that supposed to mean? LYNN Do I really need to spell it out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah stands stunned. Sad. Blank. She pulls the packet of photos out of her bag and holds them out to Lynn. NORAH Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn takes the packet. As she walks back to the reclining blood donors she tosses the photos in a trash can. A smiling Korean woman gives Norah a cup of juice and put `I gave blood today' sticker on her chest.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TINGLEY PARK- DAY
dialogues.text: Joe sits on a bench near the pond with his feet propped u a canister of Fancy Corn. He reaches into the open canist next to him and pulls out a handful of gourmet corn.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A few pieces land in his mouth, the remainder he tosses t flotilla of ducks. Joe smiles as the greedy little bastar squabble over his offering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Oscar struggle to unload the super wet-vac from van. Other equipment litters pavement around the van. Winston records serial numbers onto a clipboard. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I can turn this stuff around pretty quick. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. For everything. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming to my party? Awkward moment. Rose looks from Oscar to Winston. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Hinkle's Saturday for Oscar's birthday. It'd be great if you came. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a blast. Rose smiles at the sincere enthusiasm in Winston's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose steps out of the shower and wraps her hair in a towe As she walks past the mirror she plucks off the affirmati note and tosses it in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, Oscar, Joe and Winston sit in a carnival like restaurant. Oscar opens a gift in the shape of a binocula case. He beams with anticipation. Oscar snaps open the case and pulls out the old familiar of binoculars. Rose looks disappointed. Oscar looks confu JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That other pair we looked at, full of gadgets and gimmicks. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE (cont'd) They just didn't have the heft you want in a pair of lenses. No weight. No history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar nods. Joe points to the old binoculars. JOE These here are the real deal. I want you to have them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar smiles. Rose shakes her head. It's not like she did see this coming. But still. ROSE Dad, you promised him those others. From the store. He's been talking about it for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe looks at Rose with new found confidence. JOE No Rose, I want to him to have these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston eyes the binoculars. WINSTON Wow, is that an old Zeiss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe nods. WINSTON Porro prism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe nods full of pride. JOE Eight by thirty Jenoptems. No marks on the objectives. Perfect bloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston looks at Oscar. WINSTON You got yourself some classic binoculars there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah walks in. NORAH Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah noogies Oscar and drops a gift in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH (to Winston)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Norah kisses Joe on the cheek and ignores Rose. Rose gets JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Rose walks to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose splashes water on her face. Norah walks in and leans against the counter. Rose makes no sign of acknowledgemen Norah grabs some paper towel and holds it out for her sis NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston cleans up pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose isn't biting. She doesn't even look at Norah. She le past Norah and gets her own paper towel. Norah tries agai NORAH I read somewhere that beauty is really all about symmetry. Like having eyes the same size and all that. (pause) So, you know, when you factor that in he's like, hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose won't play. She dabs her face and ignores Norah. Nor walks to the door, starts to leave, then turns around. NORAH Listen, I know I fucked up, okay? Like really huge and I know that and I'm sorry, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bullshit apology. More defensive than sincere. Jus the thing that pushes Rose's buttons. ROSE God, that drives me crazy! That whole `Oh, I'm sorry, I'm just a big fuck up' routine. Like that's a legitimate excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah's defensiveness loosens its grip. She steps towards Rose. This is hard for her. Sincerity is not her strong s NORAH I really am sorry. But it really isn't all my fault, Rose. ROSE I think there's something wrong with you. The way your brain works. I mean, what the hell? It's like you can't be trusted with anything. You just screw around all the time like it's all a big fucking game. It wasn't a game, Norah. We're not all just here for your amusement. You should have been paying attention. You should have been focused on the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose finally hears herself. It's all the same old stuff. grinds to a stop. She knows it wasn't all Norah's fault.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finished?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I should have been there. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now? ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got some ideas. I was thinking maybe we could-- Norah shakes her head. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got my own ideas. Rose nods. As they exit, she turns to Norah. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you really think he's hot? NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Norah return from the bathroom. Joe eyeballs the girls in silent appraisal of the situation. Seems okay. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna open my present? Oscar opens the package of fake tattoos. OSCAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy said that if you're careful they'll last a whole month. And these aren't stupid kiddie unicorns and shit. They're all based on classic biker designs. Oscar picks up one of the tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OSCAR Cool. ROSE What's that say? NORAH Li'l bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks at Norah. ROSE Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar slips his arm out of his sleeve and inside his shir and stares at Winston admiringly. Rose whispers in Oscar' ear and he pulls his arm back into his sleeve. NORAH I'm thinking of taking a road trip. JOE Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrug. ROSE How? NORAH Haven't worked it all out yet. I was thinking I could maybe take the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose shakes her head. ROSE I'm selling the van. JOE Don't sell the van. ROSE Have to. Can't afford the payment. JOE No, listen... just don't sell the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose forces a smile and examines her pizza. She can't wat her father cling to another impotent dream.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't sell the van yet. Okay? Oscar slowly retracts his arm again. With his remaining a he lifts the binoculars to his face. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose tells me you make models. WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any money in that? WINSTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. The wait staff begins to sing a birthday song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose quietly kisses Oscar's forehead and pulls up the cov She turns and steals another look before shutting the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sizes up her stack of unopened bills. She opens one, sighs, sets it aside. She moves on to the next one. The TV flickers blue light into the room. Rose stops and looks at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone wakes Norah. She fumbles for the receiver. NORAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? ROSE (over the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn your TV on. Channel sixty- five. Norah clicks on the TV and watches slack-jawed as a WAITR hands menus to two hard nosed detectives. One of the TV DETECITVES looks up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TV DETECTIVE What's good? TV WAITRESS/MOTHER I recommend the pecan pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah focuses on the flicker light of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if in a dream Rose watches the image of her mother disappear off screen. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose walks toward the van with a trash bag that swishes w each step. She takes one last look, then peels the Sunshi Cleaning door magnet off and drops it into the trash bag. She crawls into the front seat and tosses empty pop cans candy bar wrappers into the trash bag. A faint sound nags her. She looks up to see the CB on. Soft white static fills the van. Rose sits a long moment before taking the handset. ROSE Hello? Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stops and looks around self-consciously before resum ROSE Oscar turned eight today. We had this whole big thing at Hinkle's. Winston came. After dinner Oscar and Norah got a high score on Centipede and put in ASS as their initials and got in trouble by the manager. (Pause) I don't know if you're in heaven or what. But you're not here and that's too bad for you `cuz you've missed out. You've missed out on some really great stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls up in her Sentra. The Molly Maid magnet is bac the door and she's in her Molly Maid uniform. She gets ou and sees Joe sitting on the steps to her house. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I wanted to talk to you about. Rose pulls a vacuum cleaner from her car. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was wondering if I could move in with you and Oscar. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just temporarily - until I find a place. ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost the house. Oh my god, you lost the house. Dad how could you lose the house? JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't lose the house. I sold the house. There's this business opportunity-- ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not shrimp I hope.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOE It's not just some get rich quick scheme. And I got a partner who has experience. I'd learn from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose's edge softens slightly. She's listening now. Joe po to where the newly painted Econo van is parked. In bold cursive: LORKOWSKI CLEANING. Underneath in smalle letters: SPECIALIZING IN BIOHAZARD REMOVAL SINCE 1963. ROSE Nineteen sixty-three? JOE Don't make a big deal out of it. ROSE Dad. JOE It's a business lie, not a real lie. ROSE I can live with that. JOE And you'd be the boss. ROSE Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With windows down, Norah drives across an open landscape. glances at a wind battered map. A highlighted route cuts across the country. Destination - California. Norah bobs her head to the radio, sucks on a slurpee. She holds her arm out the window and lets her hand surf the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, in a Catholic school uniform, holds binoculars to face. He watches a scrawny girl across the school yard.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girl ties a strand of hair to her pigtail then loops invisible strand over a pencil. She glances over to Oscar Oscar doesn't flinch. With school girl slight of hand, the pigtail rises and fa It is a magical, flirtatious pigtail greeting. Oscar lowers the binoculars and pulls his sleeve up to re the Lil' Bastard tattoo. The girl smiles. Oscar smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah walks down a corridor. The kitten clings to her. Sh turns the corner and walks though a set of doors to what looks to be a play room. Blocks and brightly colored plastic toys litter the groun Sitting in the middle of the play area is an enormous bla gorilla. KOKO. She turns her massive head and looks at No KOKO (captions) I have a tooth ache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KoKo responds with thick hands. NORAH (captions) Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lorkowski Cleaning van merges on the freeway intercha and spirals up the tangle of rust and turquoise ramps.
